{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3168251,"name":"","username":"BadAtProgramming","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T01:57:30.518Z","cooked":"

Our trajectory, when run, accelerates to max speed as fast as it can despite having a max speed and acceleration set, and does not stop when our trajectory is set to.

Some things we have already done:

  • Our encoders have a conversion factor on them for both position and velocity.
  • The tankDriveVolts is set back to 0 on both sides after the RamseteCommand is run.

Some things that might cause an issue:

  • Our RamseteCommand is in a different class with a constructor that intakes a trajectory and a drivetrain so we don’t have to re-write the whole RamseteCommand for each trajectory.

Extra info:

  • We are using a 6 wheel drive with a dropped wheel in the middle.

Our separate class for the RamseteCommand:

// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.

package frc.robot.commands;

import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.PIDController;
import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.RamseteController;
import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.SimpleMotorFeedforward;
import edu.wpi.first.math.trajectory.Trajectory;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.RamseteCommand;
import frc.robot.Constants.AutonConstants;
import frc.robot.subsystems.Drivetrain;

/** Add your docs here. */
public class AutonRamseteCommand extends RamseteCommand {

    public AutonRamseteCommand(Trajectory path, Drivetrain drivetrain){
        super(
            path,
            drivetrain::getPose,
            new RamseteController(),
            new SimpleMotorFeedforward(
                AutonConstants.ksVolts,
                AutonConstants.kvVoltSecondsPerMeter,
                AutonConstants.kaVoltSecondsSquaredPerMeter
            ),
            AutonConstants.kDriveKinematics,
            drivetrain::getWheelSpeeds,
            new PIDController(AutonConstants.kDrivePRamsete, 0, 0),
            new PIDController(AutonConstants.kDrivePRamsete, 0, 0),
            drivetrain::tankDriveVolts,
            drivetrain
        );
    }
}

How AutonRamseteCommand is called:

new AutonRamseteCommand(exampleTrajectory, drivetrain)

Our trajectory:

Trajectory exampleTrajectory =
        TrajectoryGenerator.generateTrajectory(
            new Pose2d(0, 0, new Rotation2d(0)),
            List.of(new Translation2d(0.5, 0)),
            new Pose2d(1, 0, new Rotation2d(0)),
            AutonConstants.kDriveTrajectoryConfig);

Thank you for any help we can get.

We’d need to see the entire pipeline to determine what’s going on.

kDrivePRamseteGain,
getWheelSpeeds()
tankDriveVolts()
AutonConstants.ksVolts
AutonConstants.kvVoltSecondsPerMeter
AutonConstants.kaVoltSecondsSquaredPerMeter

kDrivePRamsete = 3.1549,

getWheelSpeeds():

public DifferentialDriveWheelSpeeds getWheelSpeeds(){
    return new DifferentialDriveWheelSpeeds(FLEncoder.getVelocity(), FREncoder.getVelocity());
  }

tankDriveVolts():

public void tankDriveVolts(double leftVolts, double rightVolts){
    motorFL.setVoltage(leftVolts);
    motorFR.setVoltage(rightVolts);
    
    robotDrive.feed();
  }

AutonConstants.ksVolts = 0.14723,

AutonConstants.kvVoltSecondsPerMeter = 2.1256,

AutonConstants.kaVoltSecondsSquaredPerMeter = 1.0358

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T16:00:44.890Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430913,"topic_slug":"trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":29225,"username":"Daltz3","name":"Dalton Smith","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltz3/{size}/145991_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops/430913/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168815,"name":"MrNick","username":"MrNick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrnick/{size}/8269_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T20:00:29.896Z","cooked":"

Are you resetting your odometry before running the command? What does drivetrain::getPose return before running your command? If it is far from (0,0), where your trajectory begins, your robot will fly off to try to get there, which is a possible explanation for the behavior you are seeing.

It’s important to note that your max acceleration and velocity only apply to the generated trajectory. The Ramsete controller is not bound by those constraints and can go beyond them if it needs to to get back on track (like if it is very far from where it thinks it should be).

This is run before we run the AutonRamseteCommnad():

new InstantCommand(
                () -> drivetrain.resetOdometry(exampleTrajectory.getInitialPose()), 
                drivetrain
            ),

Is this done correctly?

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T21:34:07.697Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":36,"readers_count":35,"score":17.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":430913,"topic_slug":"trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":25296,"username":"MrNick","name":"MrNick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mrnick/{size}/8269_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops/430913/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3168949,"name":"Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930","username":"randomstring","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/randomstring/{size}/170695_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-20T22:25:22.258Z","cooked":"
BadAtProgramming:

drivetrain.resetOdometry(…

^^^ this ^^^

If you see your autonomous immediately go to max velocity, chances are you are not stating with the robot odometry set to where the trajectory is starting. The drivetrain is being swamped by the PID controller trying to get the robot back on the path and any path follow inputs are being completely drowned out.

If you post your robot pose to a Field2D object to Shuffleboard, you will see this.

Most common case is your robot gets powered on and thinks it’s at (0,0) and when you start your autonomous path at some other point (x,y) the first thing your robot does is go “I’m really far off course! I’m at (0,0) and need to be at (x,y), PID says I need 100% throttle to get there.” This is why you should never stand near the robot when testing autonomous, and have a quick finger hovering over the disable button.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2023-03-20T22:25:22.258Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":31,"readers_count":30,"score":6.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":430913,"topic_slug":"trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops","display_username":"Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":33397,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/trajectory-accelerates-to-max-speed-instantly-and-never-stops/430913/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3169239,"name":"Matt Pizzimenti","username":"mjpizz","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mjpizz/{size}/186680_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-21T04:41:16.490Z","cooked":"

We had a similar issue last year when we tried trajectories for the first time. Like others mentioned, the bot was racing off to get to the right pose, despite initially resetting the pose to the first pose in the trajectory.

One thing we discovered is our Falcon encoders and Pigeon gyro could not be zeroed in an InstantCommand. For whatever reason, those sensors needed some time to actually execute and “settle” into their zero value. To work around this, we created a specialized AutoResetOdometry command with a simple 0.5s delay, and used it as the first command in any trajectory command sequence. This was enough to make sure the odometry had time to actually reset before running the trajectory. Not pretty but it worked great.

If you’re running into the same issue, you could try switching your InstantCommand into a RunCommand with a 0.5s timeout. Hope that helps!
